comment_data.body:
Coming from https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/30460#discussion_r1798438892, this seems to be fixed:

```suggestion
---@return {[1]: integer, [2]: integer} row, col
```
because Range2 means (start row, start end), not a position. (or line => row? I didn't check this carefully)

note: since this is just a local helper function, we can also simply return two integers rather than a table.

comment_data.body:
I agree that it would make the code easier to read when not inside an editor, but what you described is exactly the definition of `Range4`:
```lua
---@class Range4
---@inlinedoc
---@field [1] integer start row
---@field [2] integer start column
---@field [3] integer end row
---@field [4] integer end column
```

I prefer to use the existing type here, and either way we do want to consolidate the many position/range abstractions we have (see https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/25509).

comment_data.body:
nit/non-blocker: do we usually prefix our namespaces with `nvim_` ? 

also wondering if we should use dot "." as the separator for namesapces, e.g. `nvim.lsp.foo`.

I don't think we have a convention regarding namespace names. E.g. we use [`'vim/snippet'`](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/blob/36890824c7edb7bc5458062c14efbfa0b1d280b5/runtime/lua/vim/snippet.lua#L3) in `vim.snippet`, [`'ts.dev'`](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/blob/36890824c7edb7bc5458062c14efbfa0b1d280b5/runtime/lua/vim/treesitter/dev.lua#L138) in the TS inspector, etc.

We do seem to prefix these with `vim_` in the LSP namespaces though, so I'll stick to that.
